user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_send_iovec_:
```c
ssize_t
MHD_send_iovec_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                 struct MHD_iovec_track_ *const r_iov,
                 bool push_data)
{
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  bool use_iov_send = true;
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.resp_iov.iov);
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.response->data_iov);
  mhd_assert (connection->rp.resp_iov.cnt > connection->rp.resp_iov.sent);
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send &&
                 (0 == (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
#ifdef _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send && (connection->daemon->sigpipe_blocked ||
                                  connection->sk_spipe_suppress);
#endif /* _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  if (use_iov_send)
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  return send_iov_nontls (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

#if ! defined(MHD_VECT_SEND) || defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  return send_iov_emu (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* !MHD_VECT_SEND || HTTPS_SUPPORT
          || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No iteration statements (for, while, do-while) appear in the function, so there are no loop controlling expressions to check against MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Preprocessor conditionals (#if / #ifdef) are compile-time directives and not runtime controlling expressions governed by this rule. The only runtime conditional is "if (use_iov_send)"; this depends on runtime data (connection->daemon fields and/or earlier initialisation) and is not an invariant expression. The mhd_assert macros are not loop controls. Therefore there are no candidate invariant controlling expressions in this code that require investigation under Rule 14.3.
